There were three of us and we ordered a large Cobb salad to share,  they divided it for us in three tiny bowls.  That was way beyond the call of duty..  

So excited to hear they serve breakfast, ready to go check it out and drink some more coffee!!  Naaaaah, I'm gonna drink booze.  For extra credit points must get a jalapeno margarita!!!

Visited this place on opening weekend, and boy we're we in for a treat. Just landed from our flights from MD. We freshened up and headed right over there, we had reservation, seated right away.The place was packed our server was a little off beat but she kept everything running smooth after missing ordering our appetizer.
The ambiance was nice, the decor is simple and chic. I must say I fell inlove with the food and drinks, I don't eat beef and had to try to husband meatloaf, the aroma was just too tempting not to try it.
The manager or maitre D came to greet us, after telling her that it was my husbands birthday and we are OT from Maryland. She sent us desert and a card wishing him a happy birthday with a 10% card for our next visit.

Upon our last night in Charlotte, we wanted to do late dining and had reservation at the Bernadin but their kitchen closes at 10...... and wanted to really relax and not be rushed during our meals. If you guessed we came back here????? You betcha, they were open until 11pm on a mOnday night.
Again The food and service were superb. Also for the quality of food that is served, the price is very very reasonable.
As we left that night I long to revisit Charlotte just to eat that meatloaf again... Ooops I went beef yall  (which I haven't eaten in more than 10years) ... I ate that meatloaf like it was my last meal...

Kudos and hats off to Nan & Byron
Great for dates
Great for groups.

Kisses to you

Oh my gosh this place was amazing. 

We went on Saturday night for dinner at 8:30. Which by the way was the easiest reservation to make ever because their website was so convenient! 

Anyways, we went for dinner. When we were seated they brought popcorn to the table and we ordered drinks. My drink was delicious I don't remember the name but it was proseco, white cranberry juice and dried cranberries very good not too sweet.  We then started wth the pick five meat and cheese platter which was awesome.  I liked that we got to decide which cheese and meat we wanted! 

My boyfriend got the ny strip steak which came with truffle fries ( yum!) and broccolini. And I got the salmon which was a huge portion(!) on top of Yukon potatoes and broccolini with a balsamic sauce. Everything was delicious. It took a little while for our food to come but they gave us a free drink to compensate. 

Oh, and Don't forget dessert! We got banana pudding and homemade Oreos. That's right homemade Oreos, and they came with a glass of milk! Both dishes were great! 

Over all I've got to say this is my new favorite restaurant in Charlotte! It's five stars for me for sure. Everything was delicious and the staff was super nice too! This place is a must try.

Had dinner here on a Saturday night. We sat at the bar which was perfectly fine as there were no available tables. 

I had the steak tacos and hubby had a cheeseburger with Mac and cheese as his side item. The meat in my tacos was underseasoned. Husband enjoyed his burger. The Mac and cheese was okay, but not spectacular. 

The atmosphere is very nice, and the bartenders were attentive. Other diners were offered popcorn while waiting for their food, though...not sure why we weren't offered any. We also got the feeling that they were trying to rush us out. 

I won't actively avoid returning here, but also won't go out of my way to come back. The overall experience was alright, but not worth the price.

Great selection at the bar. I tried a rum drink but the lemonade looked delicious. Customer service was top notch. Kitchen closed at 10pm and we got there just 20 min before. I ordered the mushroom ravioli. I love how the flavor of the mushrooms really pop out. The white cream sauce was kinda salty. The peas helped the flavor. My friend got the steak salad and said it was perfect. The steak was medium rare and flavorful with a tangy mix of dressing and fresh greens. The decor was nice, lighting soft. They have a mix of high tables, booths and regular tables. On cold evenings don't sit by the front. The large glass doors allow a lot of the cold in when opened. They had a beer garden in the back. I'd come back just to try the many options on the cocktail list.

Two stars. One for the service and the other for the decor and atmosphere. 

Appetizer- Some kind of poblano dip we shared and it had a gravy like consistency and I hate to say it, tasted like hot dogs a bit. Ran out of chips as there weren't many to start with.

Meals- I ordered the fish and chips and the coating looked like a well done french baguette. The fish itself was over cooked and the fries seemed to be out of the freezer.

My wife ordered their chicken sandwich.. Simple right? Nope. What looked like a merita bun a piece of lettuce and a tomato... No flavor at all. Then the peas and carrots side looked like something you grab from teeters freezer aisle.

Then our friend had a grilled cheese sandwich that was one piece of toast cut in half and toasted... The cheese was barely melted and the tomato soup had the consistency of marinara sauce.

The only person at our table that was happy was the one who ordered the brunch buffet. So that is a plus I suppose.

I wanted to love this place but they missed the mark big time with the food. I really regret not asking the waiter and the front of the house manager to try the food. 

They really were apologetic and accommodating and the service as I said was pretty good. But they really need to know the quality of the stuff they put out so they can serve with even more confidence.

Friends asked me to come out and meet them at Nan & Byron's for drinks and apps. It was early for dinner - around 6pm, so parking was a breeze - but they also have valet for later when parking get crazy.

Southend is filled with good places to eat and drink, and this is one of them. Easy casual atmosphere with some posh touches here and there. Whether you are dressy or casual, you will be comfortable here.

Loved the deviled eggs and the peppers as apps.

The beet burger, the kale with poached egg and the sweet potato fries - all amazing!

The brownie dessert - yum!

Drinks: The jalapeño margarita, the rosemary bellini - oh yum!

A great place to meet friends, a good date spot too.

For starters, I love the look of this restaurant. This place is very rustic/farmhouse and is very aesthetically pleasing. The food was good but I was not ~blown away~. I decided to venture out of my normal comfort zone and go for the beet burger. No regrets here, it was quite tasty. The sides however are what were lacking. My friends and I all got different sides for the most part and they were all just ok, not great for what you are paying. A lot of my sweet potato fries were burnt so that was pretty disappointing. 


Great and friendly service though and I would go back to try another dish. I got their special Gin cocktail (forget the name they call it) and it was good. Also tried some farmhouse lemonade which was good as well.

Let me start by saying that if it was just food that I was evaluating it would have been a 4  star rating...however, I have to rate the entire experience.  My partner and I visited last evening and had a nice dinner - food was excellent, the popcorn that they serve when you first arrive is very flavorful and the wait staff was efficient.  

After dinner however, we decided to stay to have a drink or two at the bar - this is where things went south.  They had one bartender serving the entire restaurant and she was simply overwhelmed.  It took more than 10 minutes to get a beer and once finished took at least 15 min for her to even notice that our beer and wine glasses were empty.  We wanted to order an appetizer to snack on, but simply couldn't get her attention.  For our check, we had to stop the manager and ask for our check, which he brought to us after another wait period.  Bottom line, they really need help at the bar during the peak hours - they honestly lost money we were ready to spend on more food and drinks....

If you are going to Nan and Byron's, expect good, unique food choices - but expect a long wait for drinks, unless we came on a fluke day where they were simply understaffed.

I was on my way to Tupelo Honey, but they weren't open at 10:30 so I decided to stop in and check this place out instead.  I pulled on the fork and bellied up to the bar.  They had a good assortment of local beer and a friendly bartender.  I decided to skip the alcohol and went straight for the deviled eggs.  They tasted as I expected.  Nothing spectacular, but still hit the spot for deviled eggs.  The presentation was nice and they came out very quickly.  
For my entree I had the meatloaf sandwich with a side of mac and cheese.  The meatloaf sandwich was awesome with the spicy ketchup.  It was everything I expected and more.  Tender meatloaf on a delicious bun with spicy ketchup?  What isn't to like?

The mac and cheese?  I think there are as many mac and cheese recipes in the south as there are stars in the sky.  We all have a preference for a different type.  I personally prefer the big ziti-type noodle in bechamel type sauce with baked-on cheese on top...almost like a macaroni casserole.  This was almost the opposite.  The noodles were big spirals and were awesome, but the cheese was smooth like velveeta.  It still tasted good, but I prefer my Mac and Cheese to have a bit of personality.
The real star of the meal was the bartender who kept my tea constantly full.  Great service and good food = repeat business in my book.

Ambiance = pretty good 
Service = okay, but a bit slow
Food = good
Prices = a bit on the high side 
Drinks = good selection but a bit pricey

Good for groups, but bring a side of patience and an extra $20 for good measure

I was excited to come to Nan and Byron's for my friends birthday brunch. I was a little skeptical though about the mixed Yelp reviews. But I decided to give it a try. I really do hate writing bad reviews but this time it's warranted. First, the service was really slow. Although we had a large party of 9, 5 of us ordered from the a la carte menus and everyone else had the buffet. It took an hour for our a la carte dishes to get to us. And there were only 3 more parties of about 2-3 people each in thise parties. So there is no need for our service to be that slow. When our food arrived, the home fries we ordered were burnt to a crisp. I posted a picture of the burnt potaties. We were saddened that the chef actually sent the plates out with burnt home fries. The bacon on our burgers wasn't even done and it wasn't crispy. They did get the temperature of my burger correct. Sadly to say, this wasn't a good experience at Nan and Byron's that's why they're getting a 1.

Me and my family came here for brunch on July 2nd. I really wanted Chicken and Waffles, but they didn't have that on the menu. They did have a buffet with sooooo many food choices. I could list it all...and I will! Pastries (muffins, scones, cookies, cupcakes), Grits, Silver Dollar Pancakes, Sausage, Eggs, Bacon, Fried Chicken, Home Fries, Carved Beef, Gravy and Biscuits, Salad Bar, Crab Legs, Oysters, Macaroni and Cheese...that's just a little over half of the items. lol

Anywho...Everything was absolutely AMAZING! I will be back soon! Oh...Service was great! I wish I could remember my server's name. Overall...A+

We've been meaning to have dinner or brunch here for quite a while, but just never got around to it.  We finally bit the bullet and went last night, as they're part of Restaurant Week.  Of all of the menus available, this one spoke to us the most.
We arrived and were greeted and seated promptly.  We were surprised when we found out that a drink was included on top of our 3 course meal, and we both enjoyed  a glass of red wine.  They have a nice beer selection, with 5 or 6 Charlotte beers on tap (NoDa, Birdsong and Triple C) and 15-20 bottles.

On top of that, seasoned popcorn (nummers) and a deviled egg.  The deviled egg was okay, but it ain't grandma's! It tasted "right", just not up to the standards you would expect at a southern Sunday lunch.

For apps - Fried oysters on top of a slice of pineapple with a sliver of jalapeno. Good, not great.  Sweet Potato Soup with a chunk of chorizo.  Very rich and delicious. We would order again in a second!

For main course, I had the CAB Hangar steak with sweet potato/blue cheese gratin and my lady had the Pan-Seared Scallops with oven-roasted sweet potatoes, caramelized Brussels sprouts, red wine bloomed cranberries.

Both were incredibly tasty.  Both would be ordered again and I will recommend this place to any well to do attorney who wishes to treat a group of co-workers to a nice dinner!

We are on a bit of a Brussels Sprouts kick as of late, and these did not disappoint. Charred to perfection and seasoned well too.

To surmise, we'll be back and in the words of Biggie Smalls "If you don't know, now you know!"

Me and my girlfriends are here for brunch neither of us has ever been here...very nice ambiance, hostess was nice and welcoming they are open from brunch from 11-3 and they hv a buffet for $23 only one person in our party got the buffet and she said it was jus ok I got the salmon Benedict deliciousness would definitely recommend give that 5*. Another friend got the French Toast it was great as well. Another friend got the tacos and she said they were good...Our waitress was fantastic as well very attentive. Would definitely highly recommend this restaurant will hv to come back for dinner one day also they close at 3 and open back up for dinner at 5...

I always recommend Nan & Byron's when asked about good Charlotte restaurants. My husband and I keep coming back here. The ambience and style is great and love the outdoor seating option. One of our favorite things is the popcorn starter. So delicious and unique. We've had the meatloaf, pan roasted chicken, steaks, and an amazing poblano cheese dip starter that is no longer on the menu. Never a bad meal and always nice service!

My wife and I made our first visit for lunch.   Arrived early,  seated promptly and server was pouring water within 2 minutes.   We split a club sandwich and mohito fries with a great dip and it was delicious.  Plus,  they offer Coke products!   My wife said it was the best sandwich she ever had!   Fair prices,  professional server,  casual atmosphere and exceptional food put this restaurant at the top of our recommend list.

Service was mediocre, food was hit or miss.  The chicken was well seasoned & juicy. The signature farmhouse burger was overpowered by the barbecue sauce. Although this isn't a kids restaurant they do have a kids menu - but the owners/chef don't seem to know what kids like. Overall our experience was OK, but we won't be back.

This place was great while it was still fairly new as I went 4 times within the first year it was open. I'm assuming it closed because not everyone felt the same way? Never had a bad experience. Not sure what happened to the South Blvd. location, but I definitely miss it. The filet w/ potatoes and red wine reduction was outstanding. Craft cocktails were always solid as well.

Nan & Byron's is confusing to me and I'm not sure they know what they want to be either.  They seem trapped between trendy bar and upscale dining.  Our server was very good, our reservation on point, and our table all ready.  But, upscale dining was a big miss.

The food was mostly a disappointment for our party of 7.  The ribeye was universally condemned as a poor cut and overcooked with many crying foul that it was a hanger steak masquerading as a pricier cut.  My daughter's pork chop entrée was returned as overcooked and missing ingredients  (the replacement was fine).  My scallop dish was tasty, however for a $25 entrée the scallops were small and few.

With so much great dining in the area, N&B is not even in the running.  Maybe if I want some popcorn and a beer I'll pop in.

As a frequent 5 Church patron I'd be waiting on this place to open for awhile. Lot's of hype and chatter went on for months about Nan and Bryon's. The good news is the hype was real! 

Really enjoyed the food, atmosphere, cocktails, and decor. Pricing was slightly less then 5 Church which is nice. Quality of food and portion size is spot on. 

A must visit Charlotte restaurant.

Went for business dinner and was extremely disappointed. Ordered Farmhouse Lemonade, their signature drink, and while tasty it was a very light pour. I'm a complete lightweight and didn't notice anything after 2 rounds.

Service was polite but extremely slow. No complimentary popcorn. Few patrons, waited over an hour for food while surrounding tables were served. Food was cold. We all tried each other's dishes. The mushroom soup was viscous and dirty tasting. I've never had a mushroom soup that I couldn't eat. It was like drinking gravy. Waitress didnt ask why it was untouched. The meatloaf was bland and looked old. Vegetables were frozen peas and carrots out of the bag, seriously...they couldn't cut up their own carrots. Mashed potatoes were gummy. My boss didn't finish her scallops but didn't say anything. Ordered a side of grits, there was no salt in them and they were gummy instead of creamy.

The staff seemed fine. I think the problem is in the kitchen. They don't know how to manage the orders and the food isn't fresh or seasoned appropriately. I hope they fix this, but I'll never know. There are so many better places in Charlotte to eat.

Oh, and grammatical errors on printed menu....

Ah-choo...from the girl who cannot stop eating the complimentary popcorn laced with Cayenne seasoning. Despite the fact that I kept sneezing, I couldn't keep my hands off of it either. Nan and Byron's is the newest, coolest restaurant in South End. 

They have a great menu filled with comfort food, which just makes you feel like you're eating a piece of home. Although my home never served up portobello stuffed mushrooms...I ordered that with a side of peas and carrots. Delicious! Hubs ordered the chicken and stopped talking to me over dinner because he couldn't break away from the meal. 

Parking is free (like I keep reading from their tweets). However, the parking can be a challenge, unless you are early birds like we are. It's rather small and if the entire restaurant is full you'll need to find parking elsewhere. When we were leaving other patrons were desperately looking for a place to park. Quickly eyeing us leaving a prime  front-row spot, they stuck the car in reverse, and was happy as a lark to get our spot. 

Noise level can get quite rowdy. It's an intimate, rustic setting, but not much to absorb the chatter from all the busy tables. We visited during a holiday party time and it got quite loud. Thankfully we were at the end of our dining experience when the party got into full swing.  

Looks like there is great potential for when the weather is nice for a couple of outdoor tables in the front. Nice. Looking forward to returning and trying out the rest of their menu.

Overpriced, small portions. I ordered the Greek salad. It was the worst food I've ever had. The dressing was bitter and it tasted like I would imagine dirt taste. Another member of my group also ordered that salad and they hated it too. Someone else in the group ordered the shrimp and grits. He said it was good but portion was so small he left hungry.  The other person with us got the pork chops. He liked his food.  He was the only one of the 4 that was completely satisfied with his selection.

Food was good, nothing spectacular on the small menu, just traditional comfort food, nothing to really rave about.  Atmosphere was ok, pretty loud in the main dining room and tables were seated very close together so everyone was trying to talk over the tables near by.  Service was great!  Overall it was a good dinner, but probably wouldn't go back for more nor do I feel the need to try other items on the menu that I didn't get to try this time.
Let me first off say the food is really good. The only drawback to this place is the tables are VERY close together and it is very loud. Would not be a great place to bring to have conversation.
Did brunch at Nan & Bryon's.  Basic brunch w/seafood at a reasonable price.

This is the second time to Nan and Byrons, both for brunch.  The first time was phenomenal, today was the exact opposite.  Had a reservation for 1:15 and did not get sat... ever.  Ended up eating at the bar (BARTENDERS WERE AWESOME).  I have managed restaurants in New York City prior for 7 years and have never had an owner place the blame on patrons.  After inquiring about when we would be sat the third time.. the owner "apologized" and by that i mean said sorry but you did add two people to your reservation.... In fact what he had done was place the blame on us.. at this point we had been waiting an hour past our reservation time.  He offered no drinks, no table, no solution.  Will not be returning and will be spreading the word throughout the race community as well.

I had date night at N&B tonight. We enjoyed the meatloaf and petite filet. My steak was overcooked by the manager quickly fixed it and offered to take care of a round of drinks and a dessert. We sat in a cozy booth that felt quite intimate. I was slightly confused on the service. Our waiter rarely came to our table, the manager and "back server" interacted with us more. We hope the tip was split with them.

Service is great here. Goes well with the whole southern hospitality theme. Food is alright. They brand themselves as an upscale brunch place but the presentation of the food not! 

Tip: Try and avoid ordering a cappuccino here.

Not impressed with this restaurant. I rarely ever give a one star and here are the reasons why Nan and Byron's is getting this type of a review.

Walked in and greeted by the hostess. Little early and went over to the bar. Ordered a Crystal Cosmo which was okay. Other friend joined us and ordered a water. Bartender never brought her glass of water.

Hostess comes over and says our table is ready and to check out at the bar. Ask bartender for the tab, he says he has other thing to do. He get a drink for someone else and then he takes chair and moves it and gets preoccupied with other things and not with the customers at the bar area. I am still waiting to be checked out. Hostess comes back 2nd time to seat us but I haven't been checked out. Another staff member brings me the check. I give her cash. She short changes me. 

We finally get seated. There were no complementary popcorn. We split the Signature Taco. The Beer Braised Pork was dry and had no flavor stacked with tons of arugula. As for the Taco- it is a flour tortilla- you would think it be soft but it was hard. Someone over cooked it. Asked the waitress is the taco suppose to be this hard when the other one is soft? She said that is how it is and then she says let me see and takes it and brings back the item in a softer taco shell. 

Ordered the Prince Edward Island Mussels- Not crazy about the sauce which is like Campbell's Tomato Soup. Was not my cup of tea. Have had way way better Mussel's than the ones they serve here.

We decided not to go for desert for we were not pleased nor impressed by the food this evening. One of my friends, who was here like last November said they were not on their game tonight. She did not eat her Brussel Sprouts because it was not seasoned. 

My friend asked the waitress for the check. She never came with the check. Then, my other friend asked for the check again.

This place is not even busy. Looks like more staff here than patrons.

Tonight, the food and the service was not good. Wait staff takes forever to bring you the check. No smile or customer service. The prize goes to the hostess and reception area, who greet the customers, seats them and says goodbye after the meal. They did a great job.

We will not be back. Too many restaurants in Charlotte to select from.

I stopped in here for brunch one day with my husband and could not believe the spread for the buffet they had. I was sick that day and not feeling like eating a whole lot or I would have gotten it for myself. The buffet included a drink such as a mimosa or bloody mary and of course the entire buffet which had crab legs! The price was $21 which is good when you consider one drink is about $8-10 anyway. My husband ordered it and went back several times. They had a great selection of items. I ordered an omelette and the hash browns were delicious with good spice. 
I can't wait to go back for dinner one night.

Went here during restaurant week. Lots of things to like about this place: valet parking, pleasant hostess, nice decor. It was too cold, but they appear to have a pretty sizable patio area which I'm sure would be great in warmer months.

I had the sweet potato soup to start, which was topped with sour cream. I wouldn't mind the sour cream as a decorative glaze, but it was entirely too much. Made the soup too bitter when mixed. For the main course, I asked for the Wagyu flank, medium rare. Definitely came out much closer to rare. I didn't send it back because our server was pretty busy, so didn't want to be a pain in the neck. But yeah, they definitely undercooked it. The dish comes with a sauteed broccolini which really underwhelmed in terms of taste. No butter or salting. Sort of just plain broccoli.

I think this place is close to four stars, but needs some improvements. If they can cook the meat closer to order, not overdo it on the sour cream, and add some taste to the broccoli, I'd add a star. Overall, though, a nice spot to grab a bite.

My boyfriend and I were really excited to come to Nan and Byrons from the great reviews. Unfortunately,  our overall experience was not exactly what we hope it to be. Upon entry, we were not greeted. When we were sat the hostess was very rude. Our waitress was not very detailed in the fact that our table was not given popcorn, a pitcher of water when every table had it. 

The appetizer for myself was crispy calamari. It was very spicy. I personally do not enjoy calamari with tentacles.  My boyfriend got the tomato soup that tasted like ragu pasta sauce. 

My main course meal for myself was the Chicken Pot Pie. This was luke-warm but good. My boyfriend got the hanger steak which was also luke-warm and the Mac and cheese was burnt. 

Both desserts ( Nan's banana pudding and Smores Cheesecake) came out warmer then it should of been.

We even had a table next to us that agreed with everything we said while we were leaving. 

Overall, we felt rushed, we finished our three course in 40 mins! 

We don't believe we will return.

Service was spotty and perhaps the staff was overwhelmed by Queens Feast reservations (this place was not packed) but our server didn't understand the menu and how to add drinks on our tab. 

The popcorn they put on the table was burnt and the tomato soup was very very salty.

My pork chop dish was way undercooked (pork should not be raw in the middle nor on the ends. I sent it back and they cut off the ends that were raw and bought it back. Sad.

I ordered a side of Mac and cheese for the table and it never came. I ordered a second cocktail and the confused waitress said it would not be at the special pricing so what other liquor would I like in the tropical mule, rum was my answer and charge me for the regular cocktail. This place didn't even promote special cocktail prices on their Queen Feast menu so maybe the staff should just say: if you would like a cocktail off the invisible QF menu its regular pricing. Easy 

The ppl next to us were in mid entree and our desserts were delivered to their table. Just a big old cluster fuck. I've had my eye on this place for awhile and it was disappointing to have this experience. One and done.

Small portions for the money, plates look plain and without any garnish. A wanna be upscale restaurant should not compromise on quality or presentation. Having flies around brunch buffet only topped the experience.

Did you say farm to table?  Why yes I did.  Did you say indoor seating that slides open on warm days? Why yes I did. Did you say they use interesting flavors and textures on their menu like chicken wings glazed with ghost peppers in honey mustard sauces and crispy cornmeal fried beat sandwiches topped with a avacado and boursin cheese on a brioche bun? What about the timid folks what will they eat? Burgers, steak, meatloaf,  chicken, ok. What's for dessert?  Fudge brownie topped with coffe ice cream and Ancho chocolate Chile sauce. OK. When can we go?

Expected so much more! We had been wanting to try this place for a while... So disappointed! We went for a quick dinner with our daughter and were shocked at the quality & quantity of food for the prices. 

We dine out frequently and certainly do not mind higher prices when it's worth it. Our meals were tiny and only what I'd call average. 

Example: the scallops- one of the most costly items on the menu. Came with 3 scallops. And they weren't prepared well. 

Example: the crab cake appetizer. Came with 2 very small crab cakes. Tasted more like breadcrumbs than anything else. 

The only positive thing I can say we're the signature drinks were tasty and fair priced.

There isn't one thing I can complain about here. I'm grateful to have a new addition like Nan and Byron's in Charlotte. 

I recently had brunch at Nan's, which was exceptional. The smorgasbord was heavy on goods like crab legs and shrimp with grits and low on boring pastries. I sat outside on the patio, which is super cool with its funky garage doors. I've also had dinner here, which is just as great. I am absolutely in love with the beet burger, a refreshing treat for a pescetarian like me.  

All of the staff members are young, friendly and attentive. Definitely not any stuffiness here. So, if you're looking for superior food, a cool atmosphere and a trendy crowd/staff without the pretentiousness, you've stumbled upon the right spot. Can't wait to go back for brunch or dinner soon. P.S. - Don't miss the peppedew peppers as an appetizer. They are the most heavenly, creamy bites of deliciousness.

Nan & Bryon's reminds me of a cute spot you'd find in the West Village of NYC or in Austin, TX. It's cozy, and is very different than most of the other South End restaurants. It's 5Church's sister restaurant, so expect to see some similar ingredients, but the asthetic is VERY different. Whether sitting at the bar, or in a table in the main room, its cool vibe and comfortable atmosphere is great.
Wednesday nights to Saturday nights are crazy, so make sure you make reservations! They're open 7 days a week, including a brunch menu (that will soon transform to a brunch buffet..think Heist Brewery). The portions are huge, and you get Cayenne spiced popcorn to start. Like many places in South End, it's more on the casual side. They're known for their comfort foods, and additions of spice (like siracha or jalapeno) in their menu options.

Drinks to try: Jalapeno Margarita, South End Gin, Refashioned
The Jalapeno Margarita is topped with their signature Grand Marnier "cadillac foam"...which I would basically like to just pour in my mouth.

Food to check out: Beet Burger, Chicken

Sides: Winter Roasted Brussel Sprouts (if they have them, they're a special option off the menu), Mac & Cheese

I'll be honest, I'm a past employee from Nan's, but wouldn't write this review in bias. However, from knowing all of the  "behind the scenes" action, I can tell you that the service expectations are higher than many restaurants around Charlotte. Management trains staff to be fully knowledgable on the product and service standards, and it absolutely shows. Servers and bartenders live and breathe the menu, so if you have any dietary questions/restrictions, be sure to tell them!

This is a cool little spot tucked away in the midst of the rising condos and apartment complexes that are starting to dominate the South End.  It's easy to miss but has ample parking and valet service is available as well.

The restaurant is in what (I think) was an old auto body shop.  They did a really nice job of modernizing it and taking advantage of the charm that the vintage look brings.  Very hip, eclectic atmosphere.

In the few times I've been here, I've tried a variety of things.  Most recently, I got the pork chop which is one of the more popular items.  It comes with a mustard sauce on top and sitting on a bed of grits.  The chop was good but the sauce was overwhelming and I had to scrape it off to even enjoy it.  I'm a big fan of spicy mustard but they just completely over-sauced it.  

There are some good drinks - try the refashioned if you like bourbon.  Very tasty!

Desserts are pretty good and include: banana bread pudding, pumpkin cheesecake, warm brownie with coffee ice cream on top.

All in all, this place has a lot of potential but hasn't quite reached it yet.  It's good,  but it could be great.  I look forward to seeing if they are able to work on stepping it up a little bit in the preparation of the dishes.  They recently revamped the menu so this appears to be a focus for them.

EPIC! Every time I go there it's EPIC. Nothing but great food. It's a must go to place in Charlotte. Hands down some of the best food in the city. Nothing but love for this place and the person I fell in love with there.

Have only been here for brunch. Price of an entree and 1 drink is about the same as the entire buffet which includes a bloody or mimosa (no brainier). That being said, if you go here you will eat too much. 

Typical American food brunch with some prime rib and (cold) shrimp and crab legs. Quality wise I wasn't overly impressed for a $22 brunch, probably won't bring here again, but nice to check it off the list. 

Most people make reservations so it will be really hard to go with a group without one. (Again, speaking about brunch.) The bar was open when I went so we just sat there without a reservation. 

Keep in mind, Sunday's in the South= no drinks before noon. I always forget that.

Great local spot near uptown Charlotte.  I have been here for lunch and dinner - both really yummy. The deviled eggs are delicious - I can't resist anything truffle oil!  And the kitchen sink salad is the jam.

So I returned to Nan's for the first time for dinner since the opening weekend (I frequent the brunch quite often and love it as much as the Saturday night drinks and dancing) and once again, I was NOT disappointed.  

I went on Friday night and the weather was quite awful, so I didn't think it would be that busy.  I was wrong and it was packed! Despite this, we were seated very quickly and the service was awesome every step of the way.  The manager even came over the personally check on how our evening was going.  I started with the arugula salad which was amazing.  I decided to take a leap of faith and try the beet burger (I've never had a beet burger before) and I'm so glad I did!!  The beet was perfectly flash fried and the mac and cheese side was to die for! I washed it all down with a Nightshade martini, which I highly recommend.  It is delicious and so fresh tasting! And I was quite surprised, but I finished my meal with a cup of coffee and I was one of the best cups of coffee I've had - I need to find out what kind it is!

I will definitely return for dinner and can't wait to try the other menu options!

Just went last night and was more than willing to give the restaurant the benefit of the doubt being that it just opened. However, that benefit was not even needed! Service was spectacular, came out quickly, and the food was simply SPECTACULAR. 

I am allergic to corn so I couldn't eat the popcorn that comes out before the meal, but my husband said it was simply AMAZING - the right seasonings. Nice touch! 

The food was GREAT and completely reasonably priced. Well worth it! The chips are great as a side, and the fries were good too. 

We live nearby so we walked and can't comment on the parking, but there is always parking nearby if you don't want to valet. You just have to be willing to walk maybe, oh, 50 feet. 

The drinks looked AMAZING and I can't wait to go back and try them.

Overall, definitely coming back. Great experience, the apps looked spectacular and the restaurant seems really well run too. If it's this good early on I'm so impressed.

Such a disappointment. My boyfriend and I came here for the first time during restaurant week. We went at 5:45 to avoid crowds. When we got there, we were seated at a two top with very uncomfortable chairs, so I asked if we could sit at the booth side. We were told that we couldn't because every table was reserved, but by the time we left only half the restaurant was full. Immediately we felt rushed by the wait staff. We were pressured to order quickly and eat even quicker. Each course was brought before we had a chance to finish eating. The food was so heavily salted and seasoned that it was hard to eat. The whole time, we felt as if we were being rushed through. Walking in the door, eating a three course meal and getting the check took 38 minutes. The whole time, at least 5-8 waiters and waitresses stood in the back chatting and hanging out. It was so uncomfortable seeing this as I was eating. Overall, we could not enjoy the experience because we were being rushed through. We spoke to the couple at the table next to us afterwards, and they felt the exact same way. Big disappointment.

It's hard to decide what to eat when everything sounds so creative and delicious. I settled on the scallops with Brussels sprouts while my husband got tuna with tofu and edamame. We both liked out dishes but agreed the scallops were better. The cocktails Are just as tasty as the good, I highly recommend starting with one such as the re-fashioned or dancing cranberries. While the food isn't mind blowing - it is pretty good and the service and atmosphere make the experience even better. Definitely will be going back.

First time here. They really gave the old Vinnie's a complete new look. Decor fits the menu. Bar service was good. Initially service at the table started a little slow but he picked up the pace through the meal. The food was good. Nothing to complain about, just wasn't "over the top, gotta get back there really soon" in my opinion.

Five stars for the service!  We have the most bubbly server ever!  Super sweet and made great suggestions since it was our first time here.  We came with the kids and sat outside but what a cute place with whole American goth theme going on.  Popcorn instead of bread? Sure, thank you!  A nice little touch.  My husband and I both had the gin cocktail with the cilantro syrup(can't remember the name of it) and it was delicious and STRONG!  We started with the mussels and sweet chili wings.  The mussels were okay but not the best version of prince Edwards islands I've ever have.  The wings weren't the best either.  The chicken tasted as if it were fried early that morning then reheated and tossed in sauce .  The kids were happy with their pasta and burger especially after being told the burger was cooked in bacon fat!  My husband had hanger steak maybe which he was impressed by and au gratin potatoes which he didn't eat.  After the server noticed he wasn't eating them she asked if she could replace them and he opted for the Brussels sprouts which were perfect!  My scallops were HEAVEN.  Cooked to perfection with creamy potato puree and Brussels and the mandarin oranges added a NICE FLAVOR!  The kids went for dessert which they were not impressed by but honestly I don't think these desserts were super kid friendly and I wish we would have been warned about that.  Nan's Oreos were homemade cookie sandwiches with almost bitter cookies and the plate was decorated with some sort of whipped beer concoction.  The s'mores cheesecake was okay but finished with what tasted like Hershey's syrup.  All in all I would def come back because I really enjoyed my food and drinks but maybe I will leave the kids at home

I met a large group here and had terrible service. Isn't that where we should start? Let's face it, if they had the best food I had ever eaten maybe I wouldn't have written this review but bad service trumps good food any day!
Had reservations for 7:30. Didn't get seated until after 8pm! It took probably an hour and half to get our dinner. I had the pork chop. They went out of their way to notate how it was cooked "Medium".  I don't know what the standard is on a piece of Pork, so I just assumed that would be cooked just right. Not too under cooked or overcooked. It was overcooked. Still had good flavor, but definitely not what I would consider medium. 
The jalapeño poppers were good, but not great. Overall I really feel like the service really ruined it for me. I may go back and if I do I will update my review if I have better results.

I liked Nan and Byron! It was so loud in there so you had to yell to your seatmate but besides that I really liked the vibe and decor of the place. The service was really awesome and someone was always there when we needed them either to fill our water or to check in on how things were going. 

I loved the popcorn they had out at all the tables. Since I was starving it was great at holding me over until the appetizers made their way over. We started off with the deviled eggs which I wasn't a huge fan of but my dining companion loved them. We got the poppers based on the recommendation of Nikki W and they were really good! For dinner we split the meatloaf which was tasty along with the cheesy macaroni and cheese goodness that we got as a side.

For dessert they had a brownie sundae with peanut butter ice cream. That thing did not disappoint. It could have used more ice cream but when one of the waiters noticed we had a lot of brownie left he even offered to bring us more. I really appreciate that level of service!

The food was delicious!! And the waitstaff was friendly but it threw us off when they brought our red wine out in a water glass. It didn't seem to fit the ambiance for the rest of the experience. I ate the meatloaf and was very satisfied. I also love that they bring popcorn out as a starter to everyone.

I really, really wanted to like this place more. For some reason or another, I've had Nan & Byron's on my list of "must-try restaurants" for a while and with them participating in Charlotte Restaurant week this Summer, I decided this would be a good opportunity.  My friend made reservations for early Saturday evening (7-18-15) and we had no trouble getting parking spots in their limited parking lot. 

The exterior really feels reminiscent of a small firehouse (which I believe the space was before it was turned into a restaurant) and has a very intimate and modern feel on the inside. Our waitress greeted us and let us know about our meal options. We both ordered from the restaurant week menu (which included an alcoholic beverage of your choice) and munched on the complimentary popcorn basket. I really liked the popcorn, it has a subtle spicy kick to it.  I ordered a glass of Malbec and started off with the crispy oysters. The oysters are each served with slices of jalapeno and pineapple. A nice balance of heat and sweet. Unfortunately, the oysters are quite bland on their own and I didn't find them to be that crispy. My friend ordered the sweet chili wings and I much preferred those over the oysters.

For the main entrée, I went with the wagyu flank steak. It was served with "crushed" aka mashed potatoes and broccolini. I was HIGHLY DISAPPOINTED in the steak. I asked for it medium and it was inconsistently warm throughout. Lukewarm steak is just a no-no. The potatoes were the warmest thing on the plate and they had nice flavor thanks to the scallions that were mixed in. The broccolini was just....there. I had a few pieces of it but I much prefer regular ol' broccoli.  My friend ordered the filet mignon and she was also disappointed in her meal.

For dessert, I went with the key lime tart. Of course the one thing I don't take a picture of ends up being the best part of the meal. This was a winner. I looked at their menu and it doesn't appear to be a regular offering of theirs. They should change that right now. It's the perfect summer dessert. The tart was served with blackberry sauce and the balance of the acidic lime and sweet blackberry worked so well together. Not too heavy and nice light flavors. I could've probably eaten an entire dish of that.

The service was great and very considerate but I was so disappointed in the overall meal, especially since I had been looking forward to eating there for quite some time. I'm going to blame the business of restaurant week for the meal quality and I hope to return to different experience trying out their brunch/lunch menu.

First time trying this place. I was very excited reading after the menu online. Parking is ridiculous. Very small spaces and not nearly enough. The restaurant is beautiful. Decor is chic rustic and really classy. The staff is great. Everyone was warm and friendly and checked on us often. Now the bad news. My party of 5 ordered a diverse selection that was more misses than hits. The deviled eggs seemed past their prime. The egg whites were tough.  The pimento cheeses dip is good and a little spicy but the toasted bread was cold and way over toasted. The wings were good but the portion is small. The tomato soup is inedible and more like marinara sauce than soup. The seared tuna was very good. The pot pie is interesting. It is deconstructed. The roasted chicken is very good and the gravy has a nice flavor. The 'pie' is more like a large doughy dumpling with no flavor. The veggies were basically raw. So crunchy I don't think they were even heated before they were put on the plate. The banana pudding is not pudding at all. It is sliced bananas and whipped cream in a tart. Nothing fancy or worth having again. Not a place I would recommend.
Really great variety here. Had the Spicy Bloody Mary - Amazing! Biscuits were so good. Buffet was clean, neat and had a great variety. Pleasantly surprised. I'm definetly  going back.

I really really really wanted to like this place, and I've been excited to finally try it.  The fella and I went on a Tuesday night and thought with the day (random Tuesday before Thanksgiving), time (8:00 pm) and weather (ungodly rain), it might be a little less crowded.  We were wrong.  Since I really did want to like this place, I'm going to start with the bad stuff so I can end on a good note.

THE BAD

Parking: The parking is still as annoying as it was with Vinnie's.  There's a valet, but he just directed me to a space coming available in the lot.  The fella wound up two blocks away in a random lot.

Hostess: We checked in at 7:55 for our 8:00 reservations.  The hostess acknowledged us, and then ignored us to answer the phone, which is one of my biggest restaurant pet peeves - always deal with paying customers first before answering the phone.  So, we checked in with the host.  Then the hostess seated two other groups.  We went back to the host, who apologized for the hostess and finally seated us.

Seating: If there are two of you, you'll get stuck a two-top table in the middle of everything and everyone.  The fella got bumped into countless times by waiters and patrons alike.  It's a flurry of activity, and it's cramped quarters.

Wine Glasses: So, the wine glasses look exactly like the water glasses but just a tiny smidgen smaller.  The fella wasn't impressed with the lack of wine glasses or the fact that the wine came in a glass that wasn't bowl-shaped.  He was even less impressed when the waiter accidentally refilled his wine glass with water.  Considering there was about one-fourth of the wine left, I was the least impressed (as the bill payer) when there was no comp on the wine... seriously?!?!  

THE GOOD

Food: Believe the hype about the peppedew popper appetizer ($5.50).  They're sweet and cheesy and delicious.  The meatloaf ($14.50) with sriracha ketchup was a great spicy twist on an old favorite.  (However, the mac & cheese and baked beans sides were just okay, and I didn't love that everything was stacked since my baked bean sauce kept getting mixed in with my meatloaf ketchup.)  The fella got the chicken ($14), which was a little dry but had a nice kick, and the slaw and mashed potato sides were excellent.

OVERALL

The fella has already said he'll never go again.  I'd try it once more just hoping that tonight was an off night, but... ugh.  At least get some real wine glasses!  Talk about squashed excitement.
I got the famous beet burger. Really great option for vegetarians, it was really good. Not a huge fan of fried stuff but I still liked it. I sat outside with my pup on a pretty day.

Awesome lunch on the patio on a beautiful sunny day! I've been anxious to try this restaurant since it opened! I knew going in I had to try the beet burger! Unique and delicious! My husband doesn't like beets but he tasted my burger and liked it enough to say he would order it sometime. It wasn't "beety" or earthy tasting. I had a hard time deciding on a side dish, but our waitress suggested the sweet potato waffle fries. They were good but too salty for my taste. I would order again but request less salt! My husband got the farmhouse burger and said it was good, but he felt bloated the rest of the day. Will definitely go back!! Yum yum!

This is the second time that I've gone to Nan & Byron's, once when they first opened and the second with a large party. In this review, we'll focus on the large party experience. 

This past friday night I was put in charge of organizing the dinner plans for a friend's 30th birthday dinner. My biggest pain point was the large party reservation process. First, when my reservation increased to over 10 people, I had to get in touch with the catering sales manager. The hosts on the phone would not take my reservation as they explained to me "they weren't allowed to". No problem. I can talk to someone else, but then I was expected to get in touch with that person, not the other way around, well it kinda ticked me off. Insert first pain point of customer service irritation. The next day that I called to change the reservation, I was instructed that once again "I" needed to get in touch with sales, and then I was informed that I would have to sign agreement, put a credit card on file and pay a $10 cover for any no shows. I get it - no shows and changes in reservations flat out suck, they do. However, when the most expensive entree on the menu is less than $20, I find this process a bit tough to swallow. Exhibit B of pain point. 

Now, after getting in touch with catering sales manager, I will say that she was very timely, professional and accommodating with the process. Not sure if this was on done on her behalf, but in lue of having to split up our tables inside the restaurant, we took the chances of sitting outside. Since we were gambling all our dinner plans around weather circumstances, the large party booking process was dismissed. Guess what... it turned out to be a glorious Charlotte evening. One that would have been perfect for sitting in the sweet Carolina air. Guess where my party sat... inside. After all the muss and fuss of not being able to find a table inside, that's exactly where we ended up. Strike 3! 

Moving on to the actual dining experience, our server was a doll. He took good care of us, kept the drinks flowing and timing was good except at the very end, when it took a solid 30+ minutes for checks and all. Food was average, drinks were yummy and decor was fab as always, but I certainly walked away feeling like I had just taken a big ol' swig of bitters from behind the bar. 

All and all, I might swing by for a lunch if that's where a friend wanted to eat, but it probably won't be on my list of recommendations anytime soon.

We had a pleasant dinner here recently. The waiter was very nice and the food was delicious! We started with the Peppedew Poppers. They needed a little something extra, like maybe a bit of goat cheese or some spicy heat. But, I love peppers and they were perfectly crispy! We split the chicken and the pork chop. Both were really very good. The bacon & blue cheese popover that accompanies the chicken was flavorful and baked just right. The cheddar-jalapeno grits that accompany the pork chop... I could have eaten a bowl of them by themselves!
Great specialty cocktails and even better food.  The beet burger is phenomenal and the pimento cheese dip appetizer is a great way to start the meal.

After one hour enjoying our lovely meal, we were asked to leave for an upcoming reservation. It was probably the rudest thing I've been asked from a restaurant ever. I've worked in hospitality for years and would never do that to a group of guests. Awful treatment means that I will never recommend or visit this place again. Ever. Never.

Went on opening weekend, valet told us "good luck" getting a seat w/o a reservation. There were 10 open tables!
First off, all their cocktails are $10 and I don't mind paying that for a good one, but they MEASURED each pour of alcohol in each drink. It would take me $100 to catch a buzz.
We got the mac and cheese (tasted like velvetta), chicken breast (very bland and dry), and recommended French dip (no).  The best part of the whole meal was the Wasabi dipping sauce for the fries (not saying much). I'm not one to write a bad review, but this place did not impress.

I went to dinner last night with 3 friends. It took a while for the hostesses to seat us (even though we had a reservation) and it was not at all overly busy when we arrived.  I did enjoy the atmosphere, the cocktail service was initially slow however they did pick up the pace when the appetizers and dinner started to arrive. We asked to be seated inside, which was great at first, but they opened the garage door shortly after we sat down and my friends ended up getting really hot... it is still summer here and we were not looking to sweat it out in a patio like setting. The drinks were good, food was good, atmosphere was good... Even with the mishaps on slow drinks and front staffing, I still give it 4 stars. We enjoyed our night regardless of the heat and I like their vibe.

Had been waiting for them to open for a few months after following their posts on FB, etc. Went there on a Friday night after them being open for only a week. I can say it lived up to my expectations.

The menu was somewhat limited, but what they had all looked good. They started the table out with some popcorn instead of customer bread, chips, etc. It was great. I believe it was just regular popcorn with a light sprinkle of cumin. Very subtle, very good.

We had the dry rubbed wings as an app, they were also very good. 

For entrees. we had the pork (pork shoulder) and shrimp (over pasta). Both were very good. The only possible negative is that the entrees ( at least some of them) don't come with any sides. The side looked good, but were ala carte.

Not to be left out were the drinks. They were quite interesting - more craft than your normal fare. My wife had the Nightshade (actually two) and I had a local craft beer. All good.

Service was quite good, especially for a brand new place. All the inevitable kinks were worked out.

Overall N&B's lived up to my expectations and is a welcome addition to South End. We'll be back regularly.

Nothing special here.  Went for Sunday brunch.  The buffet looked very delicious, I had an a la cart omelet that was very good, however nothing to write home about.  Service was rather mediocre as well.  Nothing horrible about this place, but nothing special either.  I will not go back, due to the abundance of better places in the area.
The brunch buffet is fantastic! From chilled shellfish to homemade pimento cheese to typical breakfast items like bacon and eggs, they have something for everyone. I'll def be back.

Last night, my friend and I ate dinner at Nan and Byron's to celebrate her birthday. It was my third visit and her first. (My first visit was actually on opening night.) We had a reservation and were seated immediately. I was glad we got one of the tables that's half booth since those are more tucked away than some of the other tables. Our server was there immediately to pour us water and bring the complementary seasoned popcorn.  

I had a sauv blanc I hadn't tried before - Frog Head I think - and it was really good. My friend had one of the craft cocktails that the server passionately recommended and she really enjoyed it. We had the deviled eggs appetizer, which were extra creamy and super delicious. I'm kind of picky about when restaurants try to get fancy with the deviled eggs, but these were just how I like them. For my entrée, I had the shrimp, which I'd had once before and it always delivers. It's shrimp on a bed of pasta sautéed with garlic, butter and wine. It isn't heavy at all and the butter/garlic flavor is just heaven. It's comfort food without being weighed down with a heavy cream sauce or some other such thing. My friend had the mushroom, which came on a bed of quinoa with two sides - she picked the corn and the mashed potatoes. She said it was really good. I'm not a mushroom person, so I didn't try it. 

Just like at their sister restaurant 5Church, I have had consistently satisfying visits to Nan and Byron's and will keep going back. I've sampled several menu items at this point and have been really happy with everything I've tasted. The complementary seasoned popcorn is always a fun munchie with which to kick off the meals. The only problem I have with it is how hard it is to decide what to get every time. 

I'm looking forward to the warmer weather to see what it's like when they open up the garage door that runs along the front. I also have yet to experience their patio seating.

Today was my second visit to N&B'S and I was more impressed my second go round then my first. Had their pan seared Sea Scallops with a fried green tomatoe with pan seared crab cake as my app. Finished it off with their smores cheesecake. Everything was great! Great service and great food. I would highly recommend this place.

Not exactly the best experience. My wife and I walked into N&B's about 7:30 Thursday evening.  We didn't have a reservation and the wait was about 45 minutes.  Not a big deal. 

We went to the bar to have a drink for the wait.  My wife had a couple of the mixed drinks on the menu, which she said were delicious, and I said were expensive ($9 & $10). We also had some popcorn while we waited, which was pretty good.

We took our seat around 8:10.  First negative - the table was right in the middle of the crowded bar area where dozens of people were standing on top of us.  If we had known that would be the table, we definitely would have opted to eat at the bar 45 mins earlier.

Second negative - we sat at our table for 18 mins before the server even came to take our drink/food order. Once we placed the order, it took an additional 13 mins to get our drinks (31 mins after we sat down).  The food came relatively soon afterward.

My wife had the mushroom and I created my own burger.  We both agree that although the food was good, it was nothing we would recommend. It also seemed a little pricey for what you actually got. 

Overall, not impressed.

I am not impressed with this place at all. We ordered the mussel appetizer which tasted odd. Service was great and the manager took the appetizer back and came back to tell us that the chef agreed. However by that time I didn't want to try anything else so we finished our glass of wine and left.

Awkward server
Overly salty shrimp and polenta
Poached eggs on a Benedict that were served hard boiled
Under seasoned Benedict 
Big disappointment

Decent Saturday brunch buffet with seafood. There were a lot of options including: crab legs, oysters, smoked salmon, eggs, grits, biscuits and gravy, bagels, fruit, bacon, sausage, and salads, etc. I'd probably like to try somewhere else out first before returning, as it was just okay here at N&B's. Nothing really stood out or was memorable.

Had dinner here for the first time last night.  Food was amazing.  Great drink menu and solid beer selection.  The beer menu is not vast by any stretch but the few they have are very good- lots of local brews too.  
Started out with deviled eggs and cheese dip apps. Eggs were good.  The cheese dip was unbelievable.  Couldn't stop eating it.  Had the Farmhouse Burger as my entree. Very good!  cooked perfectly- very rich burger so try not to eat eggs and cheese dip before you order the burger. Service was great

The decor was really cool.  I had flashbacks of the old decrepit Vinny's.  What an amazing transformation.

Went for late night, kitchen was still open at 11. Nice.

Food was ok, they were serving burgers and appetizers at that point. Fine by me. Nothing outstanding but no low points. Menu was trying really hard to be frisky, kind of like when your boring aunt makes a push to become the cool aunt.

The decor is so contrived and lame. This is the kind of restaurant that gets made fun of back in Seattle. It looks like they went into the sysco food systems catalog, opened to the chapter titled "trendy 5 years ago" and checked every item on the list. "Free Idea: Decorate a restaurant with Edison bulbs?" -Jesse Thorn (@JesseThorn) 

It's fine, just not especially good.

Not sure what's up with the other negative reviews. My wife and I went the other night and loved it. Service was great, staff was friendly and everything was wonderful overall. The food was delicious. I had the pork chop and it was awesome. It was cooked perfectly and the grits it came on we're hands down best grits I have ever had. We will be back.

Nan and Byron's is a nice place for some drinks and hang out with friends but I have to say that the food is mediocre and lacks a lasting impression on my taste buds. We ordered deviled eggs and chilled shrimp for appetizer and it was ok. The deviled egg was of creamy consistency but the chilled shrimp was rather bland. I got the salmon dish which was one of their well known dish but the salmon was bland as well. It was grilled with nice grilled marks but it was a little fishy. I did however enjoy the sautéed kale and potatoes that accompanied it. 

 The server was nice and patient in taking our orders for a party of 8 without fail as to forget anything we needed and was prompt in getting what we needed. We were there on a Thursday night and it was not crowded. 

At last, for dessert I got the strawberry shortcake. That was pretty good with fresh made sponge cake, strawberries and a light cream in between the layers. 

If I went back to nan and Byron's, it would be to get drinks and appetizers.

Tried Nan and Byron's today for brunch and was disappointed in all phases. 

First after being seated nobody came to our table until I went and asked the hostesses. We were seated around other tables being waited on and everyone working clearly saw we needed service. It was rather busy for Sunday brunch but they clearly had enough staff working at the time for the volume of people. For the rest of the meal, the waiter's attention was spotty at best and only checked on our table a few times. 

Moving on to the food, two in our party had the brunch buffet ($21 with a drink) and I ordered an omelette off the menu.  The waiter managed to spill coffee while filling a cup and walked off without attempting or offering to clean it up. We had to ask a nearby waitress at another table for something to clean it up. The impression I got from the two who ordered the buffet were disappointed with it being mediocre at best. The crab legs (selling point of the buffet) were overcooked and almost not worth the hassle or effort. The rest of the items were average and were on par with something you'd get from a mass catered event. Definitely not warranting of the $21 price. They were done with their second plates before I received my simple omelette with toast and home fries. The omelette was horribly overcooked and bland and they cut up sausage links (served on the buffet) to use in the omelette. I could have cooked a better one at home in 5% of the time it took to receive my plate. 

We also overheard/saw two other tables that had issues with their food or service and were being comp'ed or receiving discounts for their meals. Clearly there were multiple issues going on outside of just our table and experience. I am definitely puzzled why this restaurant was as busy as it was and with many positive reviews. 

I will not return.

This was the one pick of our restaurant week selections that I was most excited about. Loved the decor and the feel of the interior. We got there before the big crowd so it was laid back relaxed and pretty quiet. The servers were on top of their game and the courses were served and a perfect pace. There was no rush to get us in and fed and out. 
We had the oysters and the Cobb salad for starting course. That was the beast Cobb I've ever had anywhere. The oysters were good but were just odd to handle. The pineapple base they have is a great compliment to the heat of the Jalapeño.
Main courses.....we had the pan seared chicken and the NY strip. The chicken and green beans were perfectly cooked, the Gorgonzola popover was over cooked and rubbery, blueberry marmalade was good though. My honey's steak was good not great and the fries were a little dry. 
Desserts.....lord have mercy. Ok one of the reasons I wanted to put N&B's on the list of to do's was to try the banana pudding. Ate the whole flipping thing and dared my honey to take one solitary bite. Not really but yeah it was goooooood. I got a taste of his Key Lime tart, they aren't kidding about the tart part. Tart part...hahahaa sorry I thought it was funny. 
Anywho, the guy and I have decided that this place will def be a do over spot. Try it out the food is really good and the prices on the regular menu aren't all that bad any day.

Om nom nom. This place is great. We were here over the weekend for Charlotte Restaurant Week. It was our first visit and we were very impressed. The sweet chili chicken wings were the BOMB! The Wagyu and Hanger Steak were delicious, and the sweet potato & blue cheese gratin was incredible. We will definitely be visiting again soon!

Waiting to try Nan and Byron's since I heard it was owned by the people from 5 Church, ( which I liked okay -thought it had potenial, but too pricey). We got there a couple minutes before 5 ( they open at 5PM) but there was quite a few people in the restaurant already and at least 6 people at the bar. We were the first people in our group of six. We had no reservations but assumed coming in that early we could eat a quick dinner. We were greeted by two hostesses, which we relayed our 'no reservation'  dilemma too and they said - no problem ...but then nothing. We stood there and looked at them and they finally said.."We will not seat you till your complete party gets here" Okay, so we went to the bar. Which had 4 bartenders behind it. It was a bar for around 12 people. Five already seated and drinking. My husband and I sat down...found a bar menu and waited...and  waited...and waited. Its a small bar, the bartenders were right in front of us, FOUR of them..no one acknowledged us ..at all. After about 15 minutes ( a long 15 minutes ) One of them said without any apology, "What can I get you?" We ordered a "Reoldfashion" off the menu, a  13.00 drink. It was good and we were very thirsty. The rest of our party arrived and we were seated. We ordered the Peppedew Poppers for our appetizer, they were good, not great. The Cayenne Sprinkled Popcorn was great! That is free and refilled on the table!  We all placed our orders for entrees. There was three orders of Fish and Chips and Two Beet Burgers and a Philly Cheese Steak. I ordered the Beet Burger because I had heard it was unique and good, Everything came fairly quickly. I was very disappointed in my "BEET" Burger, It was to be fried beets with cheese and avocado. It was two of the smallest little slices of BEET fried and layed on this big bun. It felt like I was eating a burger with out any kind of actual filling - just relish. If you are serving a BEET Burger then have some BEETS on it , not just a tiny couple of thin slices,  I would not recommend this. My husband's Fish and Chips were not cooked, batter was wet and fish was cold so it was taken back to the kitchen. It took over 25 minutes to get him something to eat. They brought his back out and it was cooked and okay. The very best thing they had were the Mojito Fries and the Sriracha Ketchup. Fries were crispy and covered with mint and lime and the ketchup, well I love Sriracha!! The manager did come to the table to say he was sorry about the fish for my husband, we said it took way too long, but nothing was done about it. I was hoping to like this place but I do think it was my last trip to Nan and Byrons

My sisters and I had lunch reservation. We were greeted & seated immediately by a great staff. The food was undeniably delicious and we all loved our choices. A little bit on the pricier side but if you're okay with that, you won't be disappointed. I will definitely go to Nan & Byron's the next time I'm in town.

In a lot of ways I was torn to make this a three star review but I can see the potential in the place.  First thing to know is the parking seemed a bit tough and probably will continue to be until the newness dies down.  They have valet but when the valet parking spots are literally right outside the front door it kind of defeats the purpose in my opinion.  I will just walk to my car at that point but Baku is the same way.  

The decor is super cool, they have done a fantastic job revamping the old into a new fresh space.  With metal ceiling tile in the color of cooper, everything has a brown tint and that gives people a warm and cozy factor.  There didn't seem to be a bad seat in the place either, no seating was obstructed from some sort of interesting view.

First to the table was popcorn....interesting choice of freebie but different and I like it.  The beer, wine and cocktail selections were bountiful and I ordered a beer.  It came out without a glass (it was a can), which is ok, but probably should have asked if I wanted one.  Secondly it could've been colder too.

I ordered deviled egg and chilled shrimp apps and then the prime rib with peas and carrots and coleslaw side.  All were great, the food was perfectly cooked and arrived in a timely fashion.  The raining deviled egg champ is still Queen City Q in my opinion though.  

Service was great and the tableside manner was certainly on point.  All in all, this will be a fantastic addition to the area and I certainly expect it to do very well for some time to come.

Craft cocktails that shine and american comfort food kicked up a couple notches, all in dark and cozy atmosphere that still feels energetic and bustling.  Hard not to attract a crowd with that kind of synergy.  As the "new kid on the block" with plenty of social media presence, expect reservations are necessary, unless you dig the roulette of an open bar seat.  While parts of a dinner experience here are great, others are a bit more unbalanced, but should get worked out as the kitchen and service staff settle in.

Table service begins with drinks and the delivery of popcorn to your table, seasoned with a little siracha salt and Sazon, a latin spice blend.  Great for munching, deceptively easy to continue devouring.  The staff will not let your basket get empty, so just be forewarned unconscious munchers.

The drink menu showcases a cocktail selection that is relatively brief but clearly thoughtful with ingredients like cilantro simple syrup and a host of muddled fruits.  Bitters also figure in a number of drinks.  I tried the Southend Gin and was quite pleased, as this gin-based drink rose above the sum of its parts to be both bright and refreshing, without being too sweet.  The wife went darker, with the bar's take on an Old Fashioned.  Again, the mix of fruits and rye whiskey was skillful and allowed each ingredient to play its role.  Clearly a sipping drink, as it was quite potent.  A small selection of local beers and a small collection of wines round out this menu.

To start, we tried the deviled egg appetizer, which comes 4 pieces to an order.  They were good, with a nice creamy texture to contrast against the firmness of the egg, but there was nothing really popping here.  Given the menu's prevalence of peppers, this felt a bit like an opportunity missed.  

For entrees we gave the meatloaf and the chicken a try.  Meatloaf was a manageable slab that benefitted from the kick of the siracha ketchup.  I had it served with a special side of brussel sprouts and the mojito fries, which are hand-cut fries mixed with mint and lime salt.  The chicken came with our picks of mac and cheese and a side of corn.  The chicken was a full quarter, with a smooth green sauce very sparingly dolloped along the edge of the chicken.  Sadly, it was a bit dry, especially compared to other local restaurants that focus on rotisserie chicken with South American spices and flavors.  Upon asking for additional green sauce to help with this, it was a bit of a poke in the eye to find a $.50 surcharge on the bill.

In both cases, the kitchen has a clear penchant for trying to present the protein on top of at least one of the sides.  Not sure why, other than the side portions (at least the mac and cheese and brussel sprouts) were quite small.  As in, "we could count the number of pasta pieces served in the mac and cheese on 2 hands," small.  Same for the sprouts.  Both were quite well prepared, just disproportionately small, and this coming from a guy who strongly believes in quality over quantity.  The fries order was properly sized, but the very heavy amount of salt used made them hard to devour, even if I did like the flavor combo of lime and mint on my potatoes.  Unfortunately this was the weakest portion of the meal and is hopefully something that evolves as the kitchen gets its feet firmer on the ground.

Service was fast and expedient, and I like the "all hands on deck" approach whereby your food and drink are delivered by anyone who happens to be close when the order is pushed out from the bar or kitchen.  Even on a Friday night we got in and out in just under an hour.  If that sounds a bit rushed, you're right, though our server was always gracious to check in without being too pushy.  A slightly more relaxed pace would suit the vibe inside, though, and this is something that should settle down as time wears on. 

While this first menu might not be a true foodie stop for truly inventive cuisine, it shows there are many sparks of promise here and the kitchen is led by a team from which great things are expected.  So I certainly will come back, sample through more of the menu and then watch as things evolve.  The space is great and the drinks are, alone, worth a trip in.  With time, and a settling in, this restaurant will be an asset to the city and a welcome addition to dining and drink options in Southend.

I hate not giving this place a better review based on the food alone but I have to do it. The crispy beet burger is amazing! It's worth trying at least once. The issue I have is being overcharged. We ordered 2 cheeseburgers for the kids and got charged extra for cheese. We were also charged extra for ordering fruit as a side when it was listed on the kids menu as an option. It took us an additional 15 minutes to get the bill re-calculated so we could leave. The management needs to fix this. If things are extra, disclose it on the menu, or tell your waiters to disclose it.

I've been to Nan and Byron's several times and give them a solid 4 stars. Lunch is great - the meatloaf, tacos, French dip are all stellar. Their restaurant week menu was lovely. Brunch is a standard Charlotte brunch buffet, nothing too amazing there. But if you're looking for quality, no frills brunch convenient to the South End area - Nan and Byrons is worth a stop. As far as service goes: when they're good... they're GREAT, but it's been hit or miss in my experience.

High class service and delicious food! We had a wonderful server and awesome experience. We sat on the patio and enjoyed a delicious brunch of eggs Benedict and Classic eggs over medium.

Service was great; we were promptly seated and our server (Ryan) so beyond friendly and very knowledgeable about the restaurant and good. The buffet looked out of this world but we ordered off the menu, which was equally as good!

I would recommend this for a casual and enjoyable brunch on Sunday! Cheers!

The food wasn't bad, but not for the price. The Chili fries (I forget what they called them) were awful. The Server was very slow, but he was very nice. The owner, or one of the owners, came by the table to see how we were doing, we told him our issues. He was Actually the rudest person we've ever come across, and solely because of him we will not be going back to Nan's nor to 5 church!  Definitely do not recommend it.

Great meal and the Valentine's menu was a good bargain.  The Lamb was cooked perfect and very flavorful.  Our server Meghan (sp?) was wonderful attentive enough to take good care of us and not too intrusive.  The scallops were tender, cooked perfect and tasted so fresh.   Crap cakes and tuna tartar were spectacular first courses.   Although my favorite was the Saint's Cut bourbon cocktail!!   Very lively spot and hard not to have fun.

We were in from out of town and reviewed several article for the best places to go for brunch. Nan and Byron's was one of the five or so that consistently were on all of the lists. They had a very good variety of items on the brunch buffet, including vegetarian options. The sweets were very good. Come of the salads on the average side. A couple of stir fry options that were there I can't comment on because they were near empty when we checked them out at 1130, and they were still next to empty not having been refilled the entire time of our stay. The best item on the buffet was the fried chicken to be honest. I really would have expected the buffet to have been a bit better than this for it to have been on the top ten of every list we looked at, perhaps it was an off day for them I don't know.

The rudest staff I've encountered at a restaurant! The hostess was quite possibly the rudest girl I've ever encountered!!! We did the brunch buffet at 12p which was a huge disappointment. They ran out of biscuits, deviled eggs, potatoes.... No fruit. What actually was on the buffet was cold and not good. Not worth the $25....
This is a cool place and great for a date night.  The pork chops with cheese grits were fabulous!!! The Brussel sprouts were delicious as well. Call ahead and make reservations.

We chose Nan and Byron's for our Mother's Day brunch, and couldn't have been more pleased. The setting was casual enough for our 4-year-old to not be a distraction, the service friendly, and the food outstanding.
