When I can't make up my mind on where to go for dinner, I always choose N&B's as it's always a safe bet! 

If you're visiting or new to the area, give this place a try! You won't regret it.

My wife and my daughter and I gave Nan & Byron's a try for their Sunday Brunch buffet. Nice selection with a few of the usual items - scrambled eggs, sausage links, bacon, biscuits, grits - and a few that were a bit more unusual including a huge tray of oysters, large shrimp, meatloaf squares and a good few things made with sweet potatoes.

I particularly enjoyed the shrimp (with a New Orleans remoulade, but would have preferred a classic cocktail sauce) and the sweet potato au gratin. Sliced salmon was good too, but I didn't really feel like waiting for the toaster to toast.

Service was okay with a waiter who refilled Diet Coke often but coffee not as much. I think he was maybe disappointed that we didn't go all in for the refillable mimosas or bloody marys. We're not all booze drinkers, ya know?

Parking's challenging with a small lot but there are some spots to be found on the street.

Stopped in for lunch on a Friday.  When we arrived the hostess was on the phone, but was quick to seat us after she hung up.

We were seated in the dining room, which at the time, was maybe 20% full.  By the time we left around 1:00pm, the dining room was completely full.  I like the layout and the feel of the dining room with lots of natural light coming in from the windows and the garage door.

We started with an app of Train Wreck Fries ($10), which our waiter said was the perfect size for a group of four (which was the exact number of people in our party!).  I was disappointed that when the fries came out, the dish was significantly smaller than I expected.  The taste was decent, but not worth the money.

For my entree, I chose the Meatloaf Sandwich (sans mayo) with mac and cheese as my side.  The sandwich arrived looking pretty on a brioche bun (which is the bread used in all sandwiches, per our waiter).  I was excited because of the siracha ketchup that was on the sandwich, but was disappointed that the amount was too small to make a taste impact (they did provide additional siracha ketchup on request).  The taste was good, but didn't wow me.  I think the sandwich would have been better with a thicker slice of meatloaf which would better the meat-to-bun ratio.  I liked the mac and cheese (cavatappi noodles) the cheese was smooth and the portion was a good size.

I'm glad that I got a chance to visit, but I don't think I'll be back.

I feel robbed of food and service. Ordered a veggie egg white omelette, came out with yolks. Server brought me out a new one with egg whites only and shortly afterwards a manager came out and said my meal would be comped (hence the 2 stars). Veggie omelette has very few vegetables and was greasy. Yuck. 

Others at the table complained the food was so so. I was shocked by the expensive prices at this place. Not worth it.

When it was time for the bill, we told our server we wanted one check. ANOTHER server comes out with 3 separate bills. I had to tell the server the manager comped my meal and that we asked for one check.

Horrible service. So many other restaurants in South End where your money will be well spent. Will not be returning.

A great find!! My sister and I have been looking around Charlotte for a place to get good cocktails (the perfect old fashioned to be specific) and some appetizers/tapas to munch on. I'm not usually a foodie, but our bartender's (Phil) recommendations were addictive and my sister and I each had more cocktails than we planned on they were just too good! We have made Nan and Byron's a regular spot thanks to this experience.

Recommendations: Cadillac Jalapeno Margarita, Refashioned, Porcini Mushroom Ravioli, Sushi Grade Tuna Tartare

Atmosphere is cool, service was average, food is pretty good, but pricy for what you get.

Best tip about this place: get the deviled eggs app!

The poppers were alright, and managed to keep us satiated until our entrees came out.

The maglev at the bar is way better than the cabernet. The cabernet lacked any body and fell flat as a red.

I ordered the meatloa and was underwhelmed. There's nothing special with it. The Mac and cheese was bland with no creaminess. The sweet potato fries were crispy and standard. However, it's a good value as an entree that comes with two sides.

My friend got the steak, which caused immediate envy amongst pout table. A thick slab of prime rib roast on the border of rare and medium rare. I had a few bites and it was full of fresh beef flavor, much better than the meatloaf.

The service was lovely, and that really is a huge part of dining. Not a bad place, but the good can use a little more love.

We had a weekend brunch there. They give you an option with a buffet or regular menu. Buffet is a little pricy, but worth if you have a drink. If you are taking a Bloody Mary or Mimosa, definitely consider a buffet, cause a drink itself isn't big. I had  Eggs Benedict, it was very yummy, it doesn't come with a side, but it was enough for me.

My wife and I went the Nan and Byron's on Saturday night with friends of ours. We started with drinks at the bar (beer and margarita) and the margarita was good (as was the beer). After a 35-40 minute wait we were finally sat for dinner. 

We ordered the poblano pepper dip and the poppers, bot of which were really good. And they were willing to bring move chips for they dip which made that even more enjoyable.

For dinner, my wife got the Pork and I got the Meatloaf. The Pork was very bland while also very sweet, but not in a good way. The Meatloaf was like bark and the supposed sriracha ketchup tasted like Heinz ketchup. 

Collectively, we decided that the food was better suited for room service. 

Lastly, we couldn't figure out the concept for the restaurant. It seems like they want to be southern, but then the menu doesn't fit that. 

Overall, Nan and Byron's is not worth the trip. Go to 300 east around the corner for a better meal.

Nan & Byron's did not disappoint when we went for dinner on NYE. Tried several appetizer's and chose the steak for my entree. After grazing on appetizer's I did have a difficult time selecting a healthy side option that leaned more towards a green veggie. Opted for the Kitchen Sink salad for an up charge, and it was superb! The service was top notch and the hostess's were very welcoming and down to earth. We definitley will return!

What a fun birthday celebration! I had only been to N&B's for a Yelp event, so I was excited to actually have a dinner. We grabbed a table outside, which is quite pleasant even though you're basically in the parking lot. The entire night our server was on point. She was friendly, but not too much, quick and helpful when it came to offering up dinner suggestions. The manager even came over to check on our meal. We made reservations and ate early, around 6:30. I would recommend this, considering this place tends to get busy. I really like the decor of N&B's- cozy with a twist. 
Now on to the food... 
We all ordered the red wine blend that was on special, perfect way to start off the night, follow by their complementary popcorn... spicy and a little odd, but not bad, just not expected. We ordered the poblano cheese dip. Wow, It's heavy like you would expect and served with homemade chips, the only problem, you may completely ruin your appetite with this appetizer. 

On to the main dishes- Between the meatloaf, tacos and my pork chops, everything was great. Heavy southern dishes all with a modern add on spicy grits and salmon tacos. The only downside, the majority of the menu was very heavy. I didn't think they had a lot of lighter options to choose from. The menu is a little on the pricier side- ranging from 18-30 dollars for an entrée, but I do think the pricing is justified. 

The night was sealed with a sweet treat of turtle Cheesecake, on the house.... What a nice surprise, they even wrote Colin a birthday card and gave up a coupon for a return visit. Damn, that is some good marketing!

So I finally made it to Nan & Byron's for dinner and had the opportunity to try their meatloaf.  Actually the key words there are "Had the opportunity" for when I asked the server what to try, I went with the chicken instead.   But more on that later.

The place is noisy.  We were seated in the bar area and it was cramped and crowded with bar patrons surrounding our table.  It was not the best place for a dinner group which had reservations. 

Now the chicken was amazing.  The skin was crispy and the flavorful and the chicken itself was so tender.  The sides I ordered were mac n cheese and corn.  Both were small portions and both were quite meh.

Service-wise, I thought they were off.  Water glasses went unfilled.  I waited 20 minutes for a 2nd beer.  I asked for extra green sauce for my chicken and that took forever as well.

I am not ruling out another trip to N&B's but I think I'll stick to late lunches and the beet burger.  The service is much better.  It was less busy and much quieter so you could actually hear conversations.

Nan and Byron's is a great spot. It has a rustic old wood and iron kind of feel. A few friends and I hit it up today (Sunday) for brunch. The brunch menu offers a $21 dollar brunch buffet that offers what seems like a bunch of great options, especially the seafood/raw bar options. The buffet also comes with a free first drink - either a bloody mary or mimosa. After that they are each $2.50. If you don't get the buffet your first bloody mary is $9 or $7 for a mimosa and you still get the discount of $2.50 after that. 

None of us were in a buffet mood, so we just ordered meals off the a la carte menu. I would like to come back another time and try the buffet though now that I know what they have. 

Two of my friends got bloody mary's and one got a mimosa. I will say that I think the drinks are TINY, especially for $9 for your first. Even my friend said that it was good, but not $9 good. The bloody mary was nothing special. Even when it came to the table there was no garnish or anything in the drink. Others sitting at the bar that we saw had a garnish of a pickle or olive or something. I also noticed in pictures on here that others had garnish as well. 

One of my friends got an omelette where you pick the ingredients you would like in it and it comes with home fries/breakfast potatoes. The other three of us got the breakfast burger which was basically a bacon cheeseburger with an egg on top. When you order, you order how you would like your burger cooked and how you would like the egg cooked. Both came out perfect! It was so good, You could tell that the burger was fresh (not frozen) meat. The egg yolk ran just the right amount to cover the burger and give it that breakfast flair! I would recommend trying it!
I've been here twice. Once for lunch once for dinner great service and food both times. French dip and Mac and cheese are awesome.

The atmosphere was cool, very cozy farmhouse style with reclaimed wood tables and Edison light bulbs. 

The waitstaff and management were very friendly, but not hovering. Although it was odd that all of the waitstaff were lined up in the dining room like they were waiting to pounce if your fork was laid down or your drink was a little empty!

 As for the food it was just ok. Not great not bad. I had the braised pork with Mac and Cheese which were both kind of bland. My husband had the  roasted chicken and veggies. All fresh! Simple but good.

The menu selections were simple but if done well could be good.

The best part of the whole experience was the wine because it was half off.  When I arrived, there was a huge party taking up the entire bar area - which has happened the past two times that I have been there.  It seems they would put the party in the back room, but instead they took up the whole restaurant.  I ordered the tacos which were a joke.  They came in cheap flimsy tortillas and although I ordered what I thought would be "steak" tacos, it came out as ground beef.  I seriously could've gotten better tacos at Taco Bell and wouldn't have to pay $15.  Or I could've made better ones at home from a box.  I thought about sending my meal back, but I hate doing that.  I ate the popcorn because I didn't want the tacos.  Disappointing experience from what I thought would be one of the better upscale places on South Blvd.  My last experience was just as bad, but I thought I would give it a second shot.   I will not be returning.

In a nutshell, good food marred by bad service.

It started with a hostess who seemed annoyed by her job and decided to seat all the tables next to each other even though there was plenty of space in the restaurant.  Our waiter was personable, but failed to tell us about any specials or give us a drink menu and when we asked, he described their Queen's Feast dinner offering which was strange since we were there for lunch.

We ordered the chicken soup, a side of green beans, and the famous beet burger.  We also let him know that we were in a hurry (due to a meeting) and if he could please expedite our order.  He was smiles all around, assuring us he would.  The popcorn came out quickly, so we munched and waited.  And waited.  And waited.

If this had been a full restaurant I would have understood the delay, but it was well after the lunch rush and there were no large groups seated before us.  When the food finally arrived, my girl had to immediately return her soup. The waiter had put his thumb on the inside of the bowl while carrying it over to our table.  That's a huge screw up.  When we sent it back he didn't even ask why.  Another service faux pas.  

The beet burger was as good as everyone said it was and the green beans were nice if a bit salty.  When half-way done with our food we asked for the check.  Again, we were in a hurry and let the waiter know this.  So we waited.  And waited.  There's nothing more infuriating than needing to be at an appointment and watching your waiter shoot the breeze with a colleague instead of printing out your check.

He finally drops the check off and disappears.  I put my card onto their clipboard then tried to grab his attention.  He was nowhere to be found.  I was reaching the boiling point when my girl just got up from the table, tracked him down, and handed him our check.  After all this BS you can imagine what my tip was.

Our lunch was disappointing.  Even though the beet burger was fantastic, I couldn't really enjoy it because I was so pissed off at the inconsiderate service.  If the place had been slammed I would have understood, but this wasn't even a half full restaurant.

No clue if we'll go back.  Their menu is tempting, but what's the point when the piss poor service makes your stomach turn?

Trying new places during restaurant week can always be hit or miss. Nan and Byron's is a big HIT! Excellent staff, we let them know it was an anniversary, they noted it, sent champagne , an anniversary card and small app. Of marinated strawberry and cheese , small touches that made an impression before the food even hit the table and The food was incredible! We had the crispy oysters app, the hanger steak  and the scallops both came with creative side dishes loaded with flavor. Along with its very comfortable (on a hot humid night) indoor outdoor dinning areas it was a HIT all around . Already looking forward to going back with friends.
I have many other places I could spend 50 dollars for brunch for 2 people!  They ran out of fried chicken before 1 pm. The buffet was just OK.
